title: Federal Judge Rules Major Terrorism Watch List Is Unconstitutional
text:
WASHINGTON—A federal judge on Wednesday declared that a terrorism watch list created after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks is unconstitutional in its current form, reopening the legal debate about a key national security tool used by thousands of U.S. and international government agencies.

U.S. District Judge Anthony Trenga ruled that the Terrorist Screening Database, which is maintained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and several other government agencies, doesn’t give Americans on the list an adequate opportunity to challenge their status as potential terrorism suspects.

The lawsuit was filed in Virginia federal court in 2016 by the nonprofit Council on American-Islamic Relations, or CAIR, on behalf of nearly two dozen Americans who believe they are included in the database.

Judge Trenga ruled that the plaintiffs “have constitutionally protected liberty interests” that are implicated by the government maintaining such a database and that the current process for challenging their inclusion on the list is inadequate.

“There is no evidence, or contention, that any of these plaintiffs satisfy the definition of a ‘known terrorist,’” Judge Trenga wrote.

Judge Trenga, who was appointed to the federal bench by President George W. Bush, ordered both sides to brief the court on potential next steps. The decision could also be appealed to a higher court.

“The watch list’s arbitrary criteria has long enabled the government to target Muslims based on their faith and then build a secretive network map of their associations,” said one of the CAIR trial attorneys, Carolyn Homer. “Today, the government’s unlawful surveillance of the Muslim community has begun to be curtailed.”

The FBI didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment, but government lawyers have previously urged the judge to dismiss the case.

“ There is no evidence, or contention, that any of these plaintiffs satisfy the definition of a ‘known terrorist. ” —U.S. District Judge Anthony Trenga

The watch list “allows U.S. authorities to identify known and suspected terrorists seeking to board aircraft, enter the country, or engage in other potentially threatening activity,” attorneys representing the government wrote in one brief, adding: “Terrorism remains a grave and persistent threat to our national security and civil aviation.”

The Terrorist Screening Database was created in 2003 as part of a directive to consolidate the government’s terrorism-related watch lists. It contains the biometric and biographical data of 1.2 million individuals—including the data of about 4,600 American citizens—as of 2017. The better-known “no-fly” list is a smaller subset of the overall Terrorist Screening Database, prohibiting anyone listed from boarding a civilian aircraft.

Individuals are placed in the database by U.S. or foreign government agencies, based on the “reasonable suspicion that the individual is engaged, has been engaged or intends to engage, in conduct constituting, in preparation for, in aid or in furtherance of, or related to, terrorism or terrorist activities,” according to government documents on the program.

The government doesn’t confirm or deny the inclusion of people on the list, but it does allow people who believe they are included to challenge their status through the Department of Homeland Security’s Traveler Redress Inquiry Program. The government says it doesn’t place people on the list solely based on race, ethnicity, religion or First Amendment-protected free speech.

All told, about 18,000 federal, state, and local law-enforcement agencies, more than 500 private organizations and more than 60 foreign governments have access to the database.

Unlike the no-fly list, inclusion in the Terrorist Screening Database doesn’t preclude someone from boarding an airplane, but travel may trigger additional security measures. Several of the plaintiffs reported being detained repeatedly while trying to board an aircraft or cross international borders—prompting the lawsuit. None believe they are on the no-fly list but all say they have circumstantial evidence that they are included in the larger Terrorist Screening Database.

One plaintiff, Anas Elhady, an American Muslim who lives in Michigan, reported several incidents of hourslong detentions while trying to cross into the U.S. According to the complaint, one U.S. Customs agent told him: “Are you serious? Someone like you should have stopped crossing the border by now.”

The constitutionality of the smaller, more restrictive no-fly list has been challenged with some success in the past. In 2015, the Department of Homeland Security began telling American citizens and permanent residents who were barred from flights over security concerns how they ended up on the no-fly list and gave them a chance to contest the designation.

The move came in response to a series of lawsuits filed on behalf of Americans who were denied the ability to board planes because they ended up on the list. Several federal judges, including Judge Trenga, have declared that some of the no-fly list procedure violates due-process rights.

Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.com
description: A federal judge declared that the Terrorist Screening Database is unconstitutional in its current form, reopening the legal debate about a key national security tool used by thousands of government agencies world-wide.
